title: WSW boss: Why we won’t say sorry to Arnie
text:
Western Sydney Wanderers CEO John Tsatsimas rules out club apology to Graham Arnold February 22, 2017 5:27pm by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS WESTERN Sydney Wanderers CEO John Tsatsimas has ruled out a club apology to Sydney FC coach Graham Arnold after Saturday night’s display of a lewd banner at ANZ Stadium by members of the Red & Black Bloc active supporter group. 
On Wednesday the A-League club suspended 14 members of the RBB who were involved in the Sydney Derby incident, but Tsatsimas said the Wanderers won’t apologise for the tifo, which depicted Arnold engaged in oral sex. 
“We don’t apologise for the behaviour,” Tsatsimas told 2GB. 
“It wasn’t an official, it wasn’t conducted by a player ... 
“We [The Wanderers] won’t take responsibility for the poor actions of others.” 
The interview followed Arnold’s press conference earlier on Wednesday where he said he had received no apology. 
“Apology? I would probably have liked one by now,” said Arnold. “I haven’t heard from them for four days so I don’t want one now. At the end of the day I would have hoped I would have got an apology, but I didn’t get one. That’s life and we just move on.” 
Tsatsimas said it was up to the fans responsible to apologise. 
“We encourage those who do feel remorse and have taken that banner and contributed to it to certainly come forward and express that,” said Tsatsimas. 
“In terms of us, do we want that in our game? No. We don’t resile from that, but having said that, we move on.” 
Arnold said he had been called worse and “been through tougher times.” 
“I’ve got a thick skin and I’ve been in this game for 30-odd years,” Arnold said. 
“But I think it’s completely inappropriate for my children, my family. On top of that, all those young kids that turned up to the game with their parents to watch the game. I don’t think it has any place in Australian sport. Graham Arnold. Source: News Corp Australia 
“My family were upset, to the fact where my girls have come to every game of football that I’ve coached and played since I can remember and they don’t want to come anymore. 
“It’s a strong statement from the girls and my wife, my wife is extremely upset.” The banner at the Wanderers v Sydney FC Source: Supplied 
PODCAST: Adam Peacock, Simon Hill and Daniel Garb tackle all the big issues in the game — starting with matters on and off the field from the Sydney Derby. 
Tsatsimas said the banner was contrary to the National Code of Conduct and was not welcome. 
“Enough is enough,” he said. “We’ve had a relatively short history with a lot of success but also we’ve had a number of issues in the past and I think we’re at a crossroads in terms of where we go as an evolution of our club.” 
The Wanderers put fans on notice “that should there be any further breach of the Spectator Code of Behaviour in the Active Supporter area or on any RBB official social media platform that active area will be shut down for a period of time as determined by the Club”. 
The club announced on Wednesday afternoon it is in the process of issuing 18 month bans across all competitions for the members, who were identified via review of CCTV footage from the ground from before and during the Sydney Derby. 
The individuals were seen “concealing, assembling and displaying the banner” on Saturday night, and the ban is directly from the club — not a punishment from Football Federation Australia or the stadium. 
Before being allowed back to games when the ban concludes, these members will have to undertake a “recognised social inclusion program” approved by the Wanderers. View All Comments
